questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive muscle weakness for 5 months. She feels that the muscles in her shoulders and hips have been getting weaker and sometimes feel sore. She now has difficulty getting up from chairs, climbing stairs, and combing her hair. She has also noticed new difficulty with swallowing solid foods but has no trouble with liquids. She has a 5-year history of hyperlipidemia controlled with fluvastatin. Family history is remarkable for Hashimoto thyroiditis in her mother and Duchenne muscular dystrophy in her maternal uncle, who died at age 26 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.7 g/dL


Leukocyte count
11,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
33 mm/h


Serum



 Creatine kinase

212 U/L


 Lactate dehydrogenase
264 U/L


 AST
54 U/L


 ALT
55 U/L


Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Resolution of symptoms with statin cessation
Elevated protein with normal white blood cell count on CSF analysis
Inflammation of synovial spaces on ultrasound
Perifascicular and perivascular infiltration on muscle biopsy
Dystrophin gene mutation on genetic analysis
Elevated serum TSH and decreased fT4

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Resolution with cessation of statin therapy would occur in statin-induced myopathy, which typically manifests with symmetric, proximal muscle weakness (difficulties rising from chairs, raising the arms above the head, or climbing stairs) and often elevated serum creatine kinase levels. However, in statin-induced myopathy, ESR is typically within normal limits. While this patient has a 5-year history of hyperlipidemia treated with fluvastatin, statin-induced myopathy typically occurs within weeks to months after initiation of therapy. Furthermore, among all statins fluvastatin is associated with the lowest risk of myopathy. While statin-induced myopathy cannot be entirely excluded in this patient, another diagnosis is more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Inflammatory cellular infiltrates of cytotoxic T cells within muscle fascicles are a characteristic finding on histological examination of muscle biopsies in patients with PM. The most common clinical feature of PM is slowly progressive, symmetric proximal muscle weakness, typically including the deltoids and the hip flexors. Dysphagia for solids may occur due to the involvement of the upper esophageal striated muscles. Laboratory findings are typically nonspecific, with mildly elevated levels of inflammatory markers (e.g., CRP, ESR) and muscle enzymes (e.g., creatine kinase, lactate dehydrogenase, AST, and ALT), as found in this patient. Other possible laboratory findings include elevations of myoglobin and autoantibodies (e.g. antinuclear antibodies, myositis-specific antibodies). Muscle biopsy is the confirmatory test of choice for inflammatory myopathies (see table “Differential diagnoses of myopathies”).

The first-line treatment for PM is systemic corticosteroids, which improve strength and muscle function. In patients who cannot tolerate steroids, other immunosuppressive agents, e.g., rituximab, are used.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated CSF protein with normal CSF white blood cell count, i.e., albuminocytologic dissociation, is present in the majority of patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). GBS typically occurs within weeks of a respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection and manifests as a rapidly progressive, symmetric, ascending muscle weakness with decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes (DTRs). Although this patient presents with progressive, symmetric muscle weakness, the duration of her symptoms, a pattern of proximal muscle weakness, the presence of normal DTRs, and the absence of an antecedent illness are not consistent with GBS.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of synovial structures (e.g., of the subacromial or subdeltoid bursas, of the glenohumeral joint) on ultrasound may be seen in polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). PMR typically presents clinically with symmetrical pain and stiffness in the shoulder and hip girdles. Stiffness is worse in the morning and pain is worse with movement. Patients do not have true muscle weakness, though they may feel limited by stiffness and/or pain. Nonspecific inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) are characteristically elevated, but muscle enzymes (e.g., creatine kinase) are not.

E) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory cellular infiltrates of B cells around muscle fascicles (perifascicular) and capillaries (perivascular) are a characteristic finding in muscle biopsies of patients with dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis typically also presents with slowly progressive, symmetrical, proximal muscle weakness, mild muscle ache, and increased serum creatine kinase, as in this patient. However, patients would also have characteristic skin findings such as Gottron papules, a heliotrope rash, and/or a shawl sign.

F) INCORRECT:

Positive anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies (Anti-AChR-Ab) are characteristic of myasthenia gravis (MG), which can present with dysphagia and proximal muscle weakness with normal DTRs and intact sensation. However, the clinical course is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with use (e.g., worse at the end of the day or with exercise), and the majority of patients have involvement of ocular muscles, with complaints of double vision and/or drooping eyelids. Serum muscle enzymes (e.g., creatine kinase) are typically within normal limits.

G) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the dystrophin gene in the X chromosome is consistent with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) or Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), both of which are characterized by proximal muscle weakness and elevated serum creatine kinase. However, because of their X-linked inheritance they virtually only affect male patients. DMD typically presents early in childhood, and BMD presents later during adolescence. Atrophy of proximal muscles, calf hypertrophy, and decreased DTRs in the knee joint are other important clinical features of both DMD and BMD. Most patients with BMD and DMD die before the age of 40 as result of cardiomyopathy or respiratory muscle weakness, and those who survive would have severe skeletal deformities (e.g., joint contractures).

H) INCORRECT:

Serum findings of elevated TSH and decreased free thyroxine (fT4) are characteristic of primary hypothyroidism, the risk of which is increased by a family history of Hashimoto thyroiditis. Hypothyroid myopathy occurs in over 30% of patients with longstanding hypothyroidism and presents as proximal muscle weakness that is typically accompanied by an increase in serum creatinine kinase levels. However, hyporeflexia and delayed relaxation of DTRs are present in most patients with hypothyroidism. Furthermore, other symptoms of hypothyroidism such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation, and/or dry skin would be expected.

I) INCORRECT:

Vacuoles within muscle cells, along with inflammatory cell infiltration of muscle fibers, are a characteristic finding on histological examination of muscle biopsies in patients with inclusion-body myositis (IBM). IBM may present with muscle ache, bilateral proximal muscle weakness, and increased inflammatory markers and muscle enzymes. However, this condition more commonly affects male patients over 50 years of age and usually results in asymmetric proximal and distal muscle involvement. Also, patients usually develop symptoms over the course of years rather than months.
questions.hint: This patient has symmetric proximal muscle weakness with elevated muscle and inflammatory markers without dermatologic findings, which is consistent with a diagnosis of polymyositis (PM).

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing muscle weakness in her shoulders and legs for 6 weeks. She is unable to climb stairs or comb her hair. She has also had difficulty swallowing food for the past week. Her symptoms do not improve with rest. Physical examination shows normal muscle tone. There is bilateral weakness of the iliopsoas, hamstring, deltoid, and biceps muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick, temperature, and vibration is intact. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.7 g/dL


Leukocyte count
10,800/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
100 mm/h


Serum



 Glucose
60 mg/dL


 Creatine kinase

7047 U/L


 Lactate dehydrogenase
2785 U/L


 Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3.8 μU/mL


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture (LP) is used to diagnose multiple sclerosis (MS) in patients with ambiguous MRI findings. MS can also cause muscle weakness, although the characteristic course of MS involves intermittent waxing and waning symptoms, not progressive weakness over the course of 6 weeks. Additionally, ESR and CK elevation would not be seen in MS. Finally, if MS were suspected, this patient would need an MRI before LP would be indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Electromyography (EMG) is used to differentiate neuropathic (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome, Guillain-Barré syndrome) from myopathic muscle weakness (e.g., PM, muscular dystrophy); results are abnormal in approx. 90% of patients with PM. If EMG findings are consistent with PM, a muscle biopsy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Other findings associated with PM include elevated antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) and myositis-specific antibodies (anti-Mi-2 and anti-Jo-1). Elevated ANA, a nonspecific finding in many autoimmune processes, is seen in one-third of patients with PM. Anti-Mi-2 antibodies are found in approx. 10% of patients with PM, while anti-Jo-1 antibodies are found in approx. 30%. Systemic corticosteroids are used in the initial treatment of PM. Immunosuppressants, IVIG, and plasmapheresis are reserved for refractory cases.

See “Differential diagnoses of myopathies” table.

C) INCORRECT:

An edrophonium/tensilon test was formerly used as a diagnostic test for myasthenia gravis (MG). Although MG can also lead to muscle weakness (including dysphagia), symptoms are usually worse late in the day and with exercise and better early in the day and after rest, which is not the case in this patient. Additionally, MG would not cause increased ESR or serum CK levels.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid ultrasound is a useful diagnostic test in patients with suspected hypothyroid myopathy, which can manifest very similarly to PM (with proximal muscle weakness and elevated creatine kinase levels). However, individuals with hypothyroid myopathy also tend to have symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, constipation, weight gain, etc.). Most importantly, this patient's normal TSH rules out hypothyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

A temporal artery biopsy is indicated in patients with suspected giant cell arteritis (GCA), a vasculitis that characteristically leads to elevated ESR. Polymyalgia rheumatica (PR) is an inflammatory condition that occurs in approximately half of patients with GCA (usually women above the age of 50 years). However, PR manifests with proximal muscle pain and stiffness, and not weakness, which is seen in this patient. PR would also not explain this patient's elevated CK levels or dysphagia.

F) INCORRECT:

Skin biopsy is a common diagnostic test in patients with suspected dermatomyositis. Like PM, dermatomyositis causes progressive proximal, symmetrical muscle weakness. However, the presence of skin involvement, such as a heliotrope rash or Gottron papules, is the main differentiating factor of dermatomyositis. This patient does not present with skin abnormalities so a skin biopsy is not indicated at this time.
questions.hint: Progressive proximal muscle weakness, dysphagia, elevated creatine kinase (CK) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) with normal skin findings indicate polymyositis (PM).

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of worsening muscle weakness in her legs and shoulders, which is especially prominent when she stands up or combs her hair. She also reports that she has recently developed a facial rash and episodes in which her fingers become pale and painful. The patient has not been evaluated by a physician in 5 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. She does not drink alcoholic beverages. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows facial erythema and swelling of the upper eyelids. A photograph of her right hand is shown. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the iliopsoas, hamstring, deltoid, and biceps muscles; there is tenderness to palpation in the affected muscle groups. Sensation to pinprick, temperature, and vibration is intact. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated creatine kinase. An electromyogram shows low-amplitude, short-duration, polyphasic action potentials and positive sharp waves. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid antibody assay is indicated in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) to screen for associated antiphospholipid syndrome. SLE typically affects women and manifests with facial erythema (malar rash), muscle weakness, and Raynaud phenomenon. However, this patient presents with heliotrope rash, Gottron papules, elevated creatine kinase, and an irritable myopathic pattern on electromyography, which are not associated with SLE. Additionally, this patient does not have other characteristic features of SLE, such as constitutional symptoms, arthritis, and photosensitivity.

B) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is used to screen for cardiac complications of systemic sclerosis (Ssc) such as pulmonary hypertension, ventricular dysfunction, and pericardial disease. Symptoms of SSc include muscle weakness, myalgia, Raynaud phenomenon, and skin manifestations on the hands. However, skin manifestations in SSc are characterized by thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, and ulcers with atrophy and necrotic spots rather than erythematous, slightly scaly papules. In addition, Ssc is not associated with elevated muscle enzymes and changes on electromyography. Although dermatomyositis can affect the heart, echocardiography is not indicated unless there are symptoms consistent with cardiac involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

An edrophonium test can be used to diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG), which causes proximal limb weakness. However, an electromyogram in MG shows a decremental response to repetitive nerve stimulation, in contrast to the irritable myopathic pattern seen in this patient. MG is not associated with elevated creatine kinase or skin lesions. In addition, this patient does not have other characteristic symptoms of MG, such as impaired vision, slurred speech, and muscle weakness that worsens during the day.

D) INCORRECT:

Temporal artery biopsy is used in the workup of suspected giant cell arteritis (GCA), which is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), a condition that can manifest with symmetrical weakness of the shoulders and pelvic girdle muscles. However, individuals with PMR typically present with acute onset of pain and stiffness in the affected muscles before developing weakness. PMR is not associated with skin lesions and abnormalities on electromyogram. Additionally, creatine kinase levels in PMR are normal.

E) CORRECT:

Dermatomyositis is associated with an increased risk of malignancies, especially adenocarcinomas of the ovaries, cervix, lung, stomach, pancreas, and colorectum. Therefore, all patients with dermatomyositis should receive standard age-appropriate cancer screening, including breast, pelvic, and prostate exams, mammography, and colonoscopy.

Additionally, all patients should undergo chest x-ray and pulmonary function testing to assess for interstitial lung disease.
questions.hint: This patient presents with certain cutaneous features (heliotrope rash, Gottron papules, Raynaud phenomenon), symmetrical proximal muscle weakness, elevated creatine kinase, and EMG findings that suggest an irritable myopathic pattern, all of which is consistent with dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive muscle pain and stiffness that worsens with exercise. She also has difficulty climbing stairs, getting out of chairs, and putting things on shelves or in cupboards. She has had constipation, occasional headaches, and a 9-kg (20-lb) weight gain during the past year. She has hypertension controlled with atenolol and amlodipine. She has used calamine lotion for the past 6 months for dry skin. Her pulse is 80/min and her blood pressure is 138/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weakness of the proximal muscle groups. She has delayed tendon reflex relaxation, with a mounding of the muscle surface occurring just before relaxation. Creatine kinase level is 3120 U/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with typical symptoms of hypothyroidism, including weight gain, dry skin, constipation, and myopathy. In individuals with hypothyroidism, a shortage of thyroid hormone leads to decreased metabolic function, characterized by decreased protein turnover and carbohydrate metabolism, which often manifests in the muscles. Muscle pain on exertion is a typical feature of impaired carbohydrate metabolism. Hypothyroid myopathy typically manifests with slowed contraction and delayed relaxation of muscles. The best initial step here is to determine TSH levels and FT4 levels to confirm the diagnosis.

Other typical features of hypothyroidism include fatigue, cold intolerance, hair loss, abnormal menstrual cycle, impaired cognition, and depression. Normal TSH levels very likely rule out hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism and are therefore the definitive screening test for both conditions.

B) INCORRECT:

Genetic testing is indicated in patients with suspected hereditary muscle disorders, such as myotonic dystrophies, which may also present with elevated creatine kinase levels, proximal muscle weakness, and muscle pain. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of myotonic dystrophies such as cataracts, arrhythmias, and cognitive impairment. Moreover, the weight gain and dry skin in this patient make another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

AChR antibody testing is indicated in patients with suspected myasthenia gravis (MG), which can also manifest with proximal muscle weakness that worsens with exercise. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of MG such as eye muscle weakness causing ptosis, diplopia, and blurred vision, or bulbar muscle weakness, which causes slurred speech and difficulty chewing and/or swallowing. Moreover, the weight gain, dry skin, and markedly elevated creatine kinase levels in this patient make another diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypokalemia can manifest with features similar to those seen in this patient, including proximal muscle weakness, constipation, and headaches. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of hypokalemia (or hyperkalemia) such as cardiac arrhythmias and nausea. Moreover, neither hypokalemia nor hyperkalemia would typically cause weight gain and markedly elevated creatine kinase levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Needle electromyography is indicated in patients with suspected inflammatory myopathies (e.g., polymyositis, dermatomyositis), which can manifest with dry skin, elevated creatine kinase levels, and proximal muscle weakness. However, the presence of weight gain, dry skin, and constipation makes another diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Testing for anti-voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) antibodies is indicated in patients with suspected Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which can also manifest with proximal muscle weakness, reduced or absent reflexes, and constipation, as seen here. However, LEMS typically occurs in conjunction with an underlying malignancy (small cell lung cancer in two-thirds of LEMS cases). Moreover, the weight gain, dry skin, and markedly elevated creatine kinase levels in this patient make another diagnosis more likely.

G) INCORRECT:

A temporal artery biopsy is indicated in patients with suspected giant cell arteritis (GCA), which typically presents with pulse-synchronous, throbbing, dull headaches. Polymyalgia rheumatica is an inflammatory condition that occurs in approximately half of patients with GCA (usually women). It typically manifests with proximal muscle pain and stiffness, which is seen here. However, it fails to explain this patient's weight gain, muscle weakness, and elevated creatine kinase levels. Moreover, polymyalgia rheumatica is rarely seen in patients < 50 years of age.
questions.hint: Findings of proximal muscle weakness and pain, stiffness, and delayed tendon reflex relaxation in combination with elevated creatine kinase are characteristic of myopathy. This patient's other clinical features indicate that her myopathy may be due to an underlying condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fatigue over the past 6 months. During this period, she has also had fever, joint pain, and a recurrent skin rash on her face. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a facial rash that spares the nasolabial folds and several oral ulcers. Joints of the upper and lower extremities are tender with no reddening or swelling. Laboratory studies show anti-dsDNA antibodies. The patient is diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus and treatment of choice is initiated. Eight months later, the patient has weakness in her shoulders and hips. Examination shows slight weakness of the proximal muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate and creatine kinase. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Upper and lower motor neuron degeneration
Autoantibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is caused by autoantibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. MG usually presents with muscle weakness that worsens in the course of the day but improves with rest. In addition, small muscles responsible for fine movements (e.g., the eye muscles) tend to be affected first, which is not the case in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion causes myotonic dystrophy type I. While myotonic dystrophy can be associated with muscle pain and weakness, it is characterized by delayed muscle relaxation following contraction (myotonia). In addition, myotonic dystrophy is associated with arrhythmias, cataracts, insulin resistance, and elevated CK, which are not present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoantibodies against myelin are believed to play a role in the development of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), a condition characterized by flaccid ascending paralysis and reduced or absent muscle reflexes. In most cases, GBS is preceded by a respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infection. While this patient's myopathy is consistent with GBS, her normal DTRs rule out this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Upper and lower motor neuron degeneration is the hallmark of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Asymmetric limb weakness is the most common presentation, and UMN symptoms (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity) and LMN symptoms (e.g., weakness, atrophy, fasciculation) are typically present. ALS is unlikely in this patient with normal DTRs and normal CK level.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

E) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic autoantibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels cause Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), a condition that presents with proximal muscle weakness. However, LEMS weakness usually improves in the course of the day and with exercise. In addition, symptoms of autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, constipation) are prominent and usually precede muscle weakness, while muscle reflexes are typically absent or reduced.

F) CORRECT:

Corticosteroids are a mainstay of treatment for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). However, their use is associated with severe side effects such as corticosteroid-induced myopathy, a noninflammatory condition that usually manifests with gradual onset of proximal muscle weakness in the upper and lower limbs accompanied by muscle wasting and normal CK levels. The diagnosis can be confirmed by demonstrating improvement in muscle strength within 3–4 weeks after dose reduction.
Image Description:

Features not specifically highlighted as being caused by inhaled glucocorticoids or by both systemic and topical glucocorticoids are caused primarily by systemic glucocorticoid use.
questions.hint: This patient presents after the onset of weakness in her shoulders and hips, which suggests proximal myopathy. Her normal deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and creatine kinase (CK) point to a specific cause for her symptoms.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressive weakness. She has had increased difficulty combing her hair and climbing stairs. She has hypertension. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She does not drink alcohol. Her mother had coronary artery disease and systemic lupus erythematosus. Her current medications include chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the patient's face is shown. Skin examination shows diffuse erythema of the upper back, posterior neck, and shoulders. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-centromere antibodies are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with limited cutaneous SSc, which may include CREST syndrome. The classic presentation of SSc involves thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc). This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are associated with Sjogren syndrome, an autoimmune disease involving the salivary and lacrimal glands. Patients with Sjogren syndrome typically present with dry mouth and dry eyes, and may also present with blurred vision, dysphagia, and dental caries. They can also have extraglandular symptoms, including fatigue, arthralgias, and the Raynaud phenomenon. Sjogren syndrome is not associated with a heliotrope rash or shawl sign, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are a diagnostic marker of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Common medications associated with DILE are procainamide and hydralazine, as well as isoniazid, quinidine, and sulfadiazine. DILE typically manifests with fever, polyarthritis, serositis, myalgia, and rash. This patient only takes chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements, however, and her rash is not typical for this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels are diagnostic of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). LEMS manifests with proximal muscle weakness that improves with repetitive use, and patients often have autonomic symptoms such as dry mouth, constipation, and orthostatic dysregulation. Rash is not a feature of LEMS.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

E) CORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are specific to both dermatomyositis and polymyositis. The presence of anti-Jo-1 antibodies is associated with a more aggressive disease course and an increased risk for interstitial lung disease. Anti-Mi-2 antibodies may also present and are typically associated with a more favorable prognosis. Dermatomyositis is associated with several malignancies, and all patients diagnosed with dermatomyositis should undergo age-appropriate malignancy screening.

F) INCORRECT:

Anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies (p-ANCA) are associated with microscopic polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis. While these vasculitides may also involve the skin, classic findings are palpable purpura and/or skin nodules. They are not associated with a heliotrope rash or shawl sign, as seen in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Anti-Scl-70 antibodies (anti-topoisomerase) are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with diffuse cutaneous SSc. In addition to the classic presentation of SSc, which includes sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc), this subset is more likely to have proximal extremity involvement and is associated with an increased risk of developing interstitial lung disease. This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.
questions.hint: This patient's proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign indicate dermatomyositis, an inflammatory myopathy (polymyositis) of the proximal skeletal muscles that is also characterized by skin involvement.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of nausea and vomiting for 1 day. His maternal uncle had a seizure disorder and died in childhood. He appears fatigued. Respirations are 32/min. Examination shows diffuse weakness in the extremities. Serum studies show a low pH, elevated lactate concentration, and normal blood glucose. A metabolic condition characterized by a defect in oxidative phosphorylation is suspected. Microscopic examination of a muscle biopsy specimen of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers can be seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy and Becker muscular dystrophy. These X-linked disorders most commonly occur in boys 2–5 years of age but are caused by a defect in the dystrophin gene, not in oxidative phosphorylation. Early manifestations typically include paresis and atrophy of the proximal lower limbs. Lactic acidosis is not associated with muscular dystrophies.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of muscle tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is considerable variability in the size of each muscle fiber due to progressive destruction and fibrosis of the myofibres. Many fibroblasts are visible interspersed between the muscle cells and a large necrotic muscle fiber is seen at the left of the image. Much of the normal contractile muscle fibres have been replaced by hypertrophic connective and adipose tissue.

These are characteristic histological features of muscular dystrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Muscle atrophy with perimysial inflammation is seen in dermatomyositis, which results from a CD4+ T cell-mediated immunologic response, not from defective oxidative phosphorylation. Dermatomyositis manifests with muscle weakness, as in this patient, but is typically limited to proximal muscles (most commonly the pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles). Serum studies show elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) and muscle enzymes (creatinine kinase), but lactic acidosis is not associated with the condition. Moreover, this patient does not have characteristic cutaneous manifestations such as heliotrope rash and/or Gottron papules.
Image Description:

Histological section of muscle from the upper thigh (H&E stain)

In addition to the normal musculature, the following pathological findings are visible: pronounced interstitial (green overlay) and perivascular lymphocytic infiltration (V = vessel), muscle fiber necrosis and resorption (green arrow), and perifascicular atrophy (green hatched area), which is characteristic of dermatomyositis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is characteristic of McArdle disease, a disorder in which the muscle is unable to break down glycogen. It commonly manifests in adolescence or early adulthood with muscle cramps, weakness, and myoglobinuria following exercise. Due to the lack of myophosphorylase, affected patients show a flat increase in lactate level during exercise testing, unlike the elevated lactate levels in this patient. Oxidative phosphorylation is unaffected by McArdle disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Endomysial inflammation with CD8+ T-cell infiltration is a typical finding in polymyositis (PM), which is presumably caused by an autoimmune reaction against skeletal muscle antigens, not by defective oxidative phosphorylation. PM presents with muscle weakness, as in this patient, but is typically limited to proximal muscles (most commonly the pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles). Serum studies show elevated inflammatory markers and muscle enzymes, but lactate acidosis is not associated with PM.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's lactic acidosis and diffuse muscle weakness in combination with the family history of CNS disease and childhood death suggest a form of mitochondrial myopathy, most likely MELAS syndrome. Subsarcolemmal and intermyofibrillar accumulation of mitochondria in muscle fibers is a hallmark of mitochondrial diseases, which are characterized by defective oxidative phosphorylation and subsequent lack of energy. The compensatory proliferation of mitochondria presents as characteristic ragged-red fibers on Gomori trichrome stain.
questions.hint: This patient's diffuse muscle weakness and lactic acidosis are most likely due to a maternally inherited condition.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive muscular weakness. She has had difficulty climbing stairs, getting up from chairs, and brushing her hair. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Muscle strength is 2/5 with flexion of the hips and 3/5 with abduction of the shoulders. She is unable to stand up from her chair without the use of her arms for support. Laboratory studies show elevations in leukocyte count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and creatine kinase concentration. Histological evaluation of a biopsy specimen of the deltoid muscle is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Muscle fiber necrosis with rare inflammatory cells
Sarcolemmal MHC-I overexpression with CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration
Sarcoplasmic rimmed vacuoles with CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration
Relative atrophy of type II muscle fibers with hypertrophy of type I muscle fiber
Perimysial inflammation with perivascular CD4+ T lymphocytic infiltration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Necrotic muscle fibers with only rare inflammatory cells would be consistent with necrotizing autoimmune myopathy (NAM), a rare disease that is associated with paraneoplastic disorders, connective tissue disorders, and statin use. It can also manifest with proximal muscle weakness and elevated creatine kinase, but this patient doesn't have any risk factors for NAM and a different diagnosis is more likely.

Unlike statin-induced myopathy, NAM does not improve after discontinuing the medication.

B) CORRECT:

Histological examination of skeletal muscles affected by polymyositis typically shows endomysial infiltration of CD8+ T cells and macrophages, with areas of muscle necrosis and regeneration of muscle fibers. In addition, overexpression of MHC-I on the sarcolemma is an immunohistochemical finding that is classic for polymyositis. Muscle atrophy is not a prominent feature of this disorder, in contrast to dermatomyositis. Polymyositis is associated with positive ANA (30–60% of cases), positive anti-Jo-1 (25% of cases), and malignancy (15–20% of cases).
Image Description:

Micrograph of a section of a skeletal muscle biopsy (H&E stain, 100x)

The normal histological architecture of skeletal muscle (striations) is largely absent. Inflammatory infiltrate of mononuclear cells (green overlays) can be seen and the sarcoplasm has disintegrated in some spots (black arrowheads).

These features suggest (poly-)myositis.
Detection of other, more specific features (such as overexpression of MHC-I molecules on the sarcolemma) would require immunohistochemistry.

C) INCORRECT:

A skeletal muscle biopsy showing sarcoplasmic rimmed vacuoles and infiltration of CD8+ T lymphocytes and dendritic cells would be consistent with inclusion body myositis (IBM), which is also characterized by necrosis and atrophy of muscle fibers. Although IBM also manifests with proximal muscle weakness, the weakness is usually asymmetric and progresses over years, rather than months. In addition, the condition is most common in older age (> 50 years old) and is more common in men.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy sample of striated muscle tissue

Vacuoles (dotted white outlines) are present within the muscle fibers. The fibers vary in size, from smaller atrophic (green overlay) to larger hypertrophic (yellow overlay).
There is an abundance of inflammatory cells between the fibers.

These are typical histological findings in inclusion body myositis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroid myopathy is characterized by noninflammatory type II muscle fiber atrophy with relative type I muscle fiber hypertrophy. This condition may also manifest with proximal muscle weakness and elevated creatine kinase, as seen in this patient. However, patients with hypothyroid myopathy typically have other symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, weight gain, constipation, and delayed deep tendon reflex), which are not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Perimysial inflammation with perivascular infiltration of CD4+ T lymphocytes would be consistent with dermatomyositis, which is also characterized by capillary damage and muscle atrophy. It also manifests with progressive symmetrical proximal muscle weakness but is also defined by skin involvement (e.g., Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash), which is lacking in this patient.
Image Description:

Histological section of muscle from the upper thigh (H&E stain)

In addition to the normal musculature, the following pathological findings are visible: pronounced interstitial (green overlay) and perivascular lymphocytic infiltration (V = vessel), muscle fiber necrosis and resorption (green arrow), and perifascicular atrophy (green hatched area), which is characteristic of dermatomyositis.
questions.hint: This patient has symmetric proximal muscle weakness with elevated muscle and inflammatory markers without dermatologic findings, which is consistent with a diagnosis of polymyositis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive weakness. She has had increased difficulty climbing stairs and standing from a seated position. She takes no medications. Neurologic examination shows weakness of the proximal muscles. Skin examination shows diffuse erythema of the upper back, posterior neck, and shoulders. A photograph of the patient's eye is shown. Antibodies against which of the following are most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antimyeloperoxidase antibodies (p-ANCA) are associated with microscopic polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Though these vasculitides can involve the skin, typical findings include palpable purpura and skin nodules. They are not associated with proximal muscle weakness, a heliotrope rash, or the shawl sign.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticentromere antibodies are typically associated with limited systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome), which presents with a tight mask-like face, microstomia, calcinosis cutis, sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, telangiectasias, and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., dysphagia, reflux). Limited systemic sclerosis is not associated with proximal muscle weakness, a heliotrope rash, or the shawl sign.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels are associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). This condition typically manifests with proximal muscle weakness that improves with repetitive use, and patients often have autonomic symptoms such as dry mouth, constipation, and orthostatic dysregulation. However, LEMS is not associated with a heliotrope rash or the shawl sign.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-La and anti-Ro antibodies are associated with Sjögren syndrome. This condition typically manifests with dry mouth and dry eyes, which results in blurred vision, dysphagia, and dental caries. Patients can also develop fatigue, arthralgia, and Raynaud phenomenon. Sjögren syndrome is not associated with proximal muscle weakness, a heliotrope rash, or the shawl sign.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Scl-70 antibodies are typically associated with diffuse systemic sclerosis, which can present with fatigue and proximal muscle weakness. However, a heliotrope rash or the shawl sign would not be expected. Instead, patients would present with features such as a tight mask-like face with microstomia, sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., dysphagia, reflux), renal disease, and interstitial lung disease.

F) CORRECT:

Anti-Mi-2 antibodies are associated with dermatomyositis and polymyositis. These antibodies, along with anti-Jo-1 antibodies and anti-SRP antibodies, are relatively specific for these conditions. Dermatomyositis is associated with several malignancies (e.g., ovarian adenocarcinoma), and all patients diagnosed with this condition should be evaluated with age-appropriate screening.

G) INCORRECT:

Antihistone antibodies are associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Medications known to cause DILE include procainamide, hydralazine, isoniazid, and sulfadiazine. This condition typically manifests with fever, polyarthritis, serositis, myalgia, and generalized rash. This patient does not take medications, however, and her rash is not typical for this diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient has dermatomyositis, which typically manifests with proximal muscle weakness, a heliotrope rash, and the shawl sign.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man reports a 5-week history of progressive dyspnea, intermittent fevers, arthralgias, and weakness.
On examination, he is in moderate respiratory distress at rest, is tachypneic, and has a temperature of 38.1°C. His oxygen saturation is 80% while he is breathing ambient air and corrects to 92% with supplemental oxygen (3 liters per minute). He has difficulty raising his head off the examination table and getting up from a chair without assistance; he is also noted to have thickened skin on the tips and margins of his fingers. His creatine kinase level is 2230 U/liter (reference range, 60–400).
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following initial therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nintedanib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor recently approved for the treatment of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and systemic sclerosis-associated ILD.

B) CORRECT:

Antisynthetase syndrome is a type of autoimmune inflammatory myopathy with extramuscular manifestations that affect the lungs, skin, and joints. It typically manifests with symmetric proximal muscle weakness, interstitial lung disease (ILD), fever, Raynaud phenomenon, arthritis, and hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers (“mechanic hands”).

Antisynthetase syndrome is characterized by the presence of autoantibodies that target aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases, enzymes that conjugate amino acids to their respective tRNA. The most common of these autoantibodies recognize histidyl-tRNA synthetase (anti-Jo1), threonyl-tRNA synthetase (anti-PL7), and alanyl-tRNA synthetase (anti-PL12).

Classifying Inflammatory Myopathies

Inflammatory myopathies are currently classified into five entities:

• Dermatomyositis
• Overlap myositis (including antisynthetase syndrome)
• Immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy
• Inclusion-body myositis
• Polymyositis

Clinically, dermatomyositis is characterized by a variety of skin manifestations, including heliotrope rash, Gottron sign, and shawl sign. In previous classification schemes, most inflammatory myopathies without a rash were categorized as polymyositis. However, with the recognition of specific autoantibodies, histologic patterns, and extramuscular manifestations, many of these cases can now be reclassified into one of the other entities listed above.

Recognizing and Managing ILD in This Setting

The ILD of antisynthetase syndrome manifests clinically with shortness of breath, fatigue, hypoxemia, dry crackles, a chest radiograph with reticular infiltrates (as in this case), and a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing.

The mainstay of initial treatment for patients with ILD related to antisynthetase syndrome and other types of inflammatory myopathies is a glucocorticoid, such as prednisone. Tapering of the glucocorticoid often requires adding a second agent, such as azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, methotrexate, a calcineurin inhibitor, or cyclophosphamide.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial therapy for patients with interstitial lung disease related to antisynthetase syndrome is a glucocorticoid.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin has been studied as treatment for patients with inflammatory myopathies, but it is not first-line therapy for associated ILD.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy with azithromycin or inhaled tobramycin is not indicated in the absence of infection. Inhaled tobramycin is appropriate for patients with a chronic airway disease, such as cystic fibrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy with azithromycin or inhaled tobramycin is not indicated in the absence of infection. Inhaled tobramycin is appropriate for patients with a chronic airway disease, such as cystic fibrosis.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man with emphysema and a 65-pack-year history of smoking reports progressive weakness during the past 3 months. The weakness is most noticeable to him upon rising from a seated position. In the past 2 months, he has lost 4.5 kg unintentionally.
The patient’s physical examination is largely unremarkable, with the exception of scaly bumps over the dorsum of his hands, favoring the knuckles (figure).
Laboratory results include an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 47 mm/hr (reference range, 0–17) and a creatine kinase level of 2840 U/liter (60–400).
Which one of the following diagnostic evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nerve-conduction studies are not helpful in evaluating dermatomyositis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s muscle weakness, bumps over the dorsum of the hands favoring the knuckles (Gottron papules), and elevated creatine kinase level suggest a diagnosis of dermatomyositis. This condition is associated with an underlying malignancy in 10% to 25% of cases, most often of the lung, breast, ovaries, or prostate.

Lung cancer is the most likely malignancy in an older patient with a history of cigarette smoking and underlying emphysema. The best study to assess for lung cancer is CT of the chest. The abdomen and pelvis are scanned at the same time to evaluate for abdominal primary malignancies or metastatic disease. In adult patients diagnosed with dermatomyositis, a CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis is typically performed to evaluate for malignancy regardless of whether or not the patient has classic symptoms of an underlying cancer. Additional testing may also be performed to complete a comprehensive malignancy screening.

Proceeding directly to conventional treatment of the dermatomyositis might cause the clinician to miss an underlying malignancy, and the treatment may or may not be effective if a malignancy is present.

Key learning point: A new diagnosis of dermatomyositis should prompt evaluation for an underlying malignancy, as it may be a paraneoplastic syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Respiratory muscle strength testing is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain would not help identify any of the most common malignancies associated with dermatomyositis.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the thymus would not help identify any of the most common malignancies associated with dermatomyositis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports 6 months of progressive dyspnea on exertion. She also notes leg weakness that began 6 months ago and has progressed to the point where she now has difficulty getting up from a seated position. She also reports increasing difficulty raising her arms over her head.
On examination, her oxygen saturation is 91% while she breathes ambient air. She has bibasilar crackles, upper- and lower-extremity proximal muscle weakness, and a skin rash (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polymyalgia rheumatica does not cause interstitial lung disease or the skin manifestations seen in dermatomyositis. Polymyalgia rheumatica typically manifests with pain and stiffness of the shoulders and hips.

B) CORRECT:

Dermatomyositis is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and a characteristic cutaneous eruption. The skin findings may include:

• Erythema and edema of the eyelids (heliotrope eruption)
• Pink to violaceous papules over the knuckles (Gottron papules, as seen in this patient)
• Midfacial erythema
• Photodistributed erythema and/or poikiloderma of the scalp, chest (V-neck sign), and upper back (shawl sign)
• Poikiloderma of the lateral thighs (holster sign)
• Pink to violaceous patches or papules on extensor joints such as elbows and knees (Gottron sign)
• Nail-fold capillary changes (including dilated capillary loops, dropout of capillaries, and cuticular hypertrophy)

Hyperkeratosis and fissuring on the lateral fingers and palms (mechanic hands) may also occur and may indicate a higher risk for pulmonary involvement.

Interstitial lung disease is one of the most severe complications of inflammatory myopathies. All adult patients with dermatomyositis should undergo screening with pulmonary function tests with diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide. If abnormalities are found, the patient should have a high-resolution chest CT with interstitial lung disease protocol.

Key learning point: Common manifestations of dermatomyositis include rash, muscle weakness, and interstitial lung disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Scleroderma, microscopic polyangiitis, and rheumatoid arthritis are all important causes of interstitial lung disease, but they do not cause the characteristic rash seen in dermatomyositis.

D) INCORRECT:

Scleroderma, microscopic polyangiitis, and rheumatoid arthritis are all important causes of interstitial lung disease, but they do not cause the characteristic rash seen in dermatomyositis.

E) INCORRECT:

Scleroderma, microscopic polyangiitis, and rheumatoid arthritis are all important causes of interstitial lung disease, but they do not cause the characteristic rash seen in dermatomyositis.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidemia reports a 6-month history of slowly progressive difficulty getting up out of chairs and climbing steps. He also notes some difficulty swallowing solid foods.
His only medication is simvastatin 40 mg daily.
His vital signs are normal, as is his cardiopulmonary examination. There is weakness of the wrist and finger flexor muscles (4/5) and quadriceps muscles (4/5) but no muscle tenderness. His reflexes and a sensory examination are normal. There are no skin abnormalities.
His serum creatine kinase level is 937 U/liter (reference range, 60–400). His thyroid-stimulating hormone level is normal. Results of a complete blood count, kidney function testing, and liver function testing are normal.
What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The findings of elevated creatine kinase levels and finger flexor weakness are not typical of myasthenia gravis.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with statin-induced myopathy typically present with myalgias and may not show evidence of objective muscle weakness on examination. Finger flexor weakness is not typically seen in statin-induced myopathy, and the myopathy typically resolves after discontinuation of the statin. Statins may also cause a rare, immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy that is associated with anti-3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A reductase antibodies. This condition typically manifests with proximal muscle weakness (sparing the distal muscle groups, such as the finger and wrist flexors) and requires immunosuppression.

C) INCORRECT:

The finding of prominent distal upper-extremity weakness and the absence of skin findings are not typical of dermatomyositis, which usually involves the proximal muscles of the upper and lower extremities and is accompanied by skin changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Guillian-Barré syndrome manifests with progressive, symmetric muscle weakness that often starts in the lower extremities and is accompanied by absent or reduced reflexes. The findings of elevated creatine kinase levels, normal sensory examination, and prominent dysphagia are not typical of chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy.

E) CORRECT:

Inclusion-body myositis is the most common muscle disease in adults older than age 50. It typically manifests with asymmetric, progressive muscle weakness that can affect both proximal muscle groups (classically the proximal leg) and distal muscle groups (classically the finger flexors). Approximately half of patients also develop prominent dysphagia during the course of the disease. Inclusion-body myositis is typically painless.

Key learning point: Slowly progressive weakness of the proximal leg and finger flexor muscles, in combination with dysphagia and a modestly elevated creatine kinase level, is most consistent with a diagnosis of inclusion-body myositis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a rash, photosensitivity, and marked pruritus.
Physical examination reveals periorbital erythema and edema, erythema of the anterior neck and chest, and erythematous papules overlying the dorsal aspect of the knuckles (figure). The remainder of the examination (including a neuromuscular examination) is normal.
A complete blood count, serum creatine kinase level, and aldolase level are within normal ranges.
What is the most likely underlying diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scleroderma is characterized by puffy hands, tapered digits, and Raynaud phenomenon.

B) INCORRECT:

Sarcoidosis can have protean manifestations but does not involve photosensitivity and may include infiltrated papules around the nose or orifices.

C) INCORRECT:

The malar rash of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can be difficult to differentiate from the midfacial erythema of dermatomyositis. Both are photosensitive and manifest with facial erythema. However, the malar rash of SLE tends to spare the nasolabial folds, whereas the midfacial erythema of dermatomyositis involves those folds. In addition, in this case, the patient has a heliotrope eruption and Gottron papules, both of which are nearly pathognomonic for dermatomyositis.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with rheumatoid arthritis may present with cutaneous nodules overlying joint spaces but are unlikely to present with the other cutaneous findings described in this case.

E) CORRECT:

Dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease that can manifest with or without muscle involvement (classic or amyopathic dermatomyositis, respectively). Characteristic skin findings include:

• Erythema and edema of the eyelids (heliotrope sign)
• Pink to violaceous papules over the knuckles (Gottron papules)
• Midfacial erythema
• Photodistributed erythema and/or poikiloderma of the scalp, chest (V-neck sign), and upper back (shawl sign)
• Poikiloderma of the lateral thighs (holster sign)
• Pink to violaceous patches or papules on extensor joints (Gottron sign)
• Nail-fold capillary changes (including dilated capillary loops, dropout of capillaries, and cuticular hypertrophy)
• Hyperkeratosis and fissuring on the lateral fingers and palms (mechanic hands)

Recognizing the skin changes associated with dermatomyositis is critical, as a subset of patients with dermatomyositis have interstitial lung disease, internal malignancy, or other systemic associations. Patients with dermatomyositis (whether classic or amyopathic) require evaluation for these conditions.

Key learning point: A patient who has skin findings consistent with dermatomyositis but no clinical findings suggestive of muscle involvement most likely has a diagnosis of amyopathic dermatomyositis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis reports a one-year history of rashes on her scalp, midface, chest, upper back, and dorsal hands (figure). She also has erythema and edema of the eyelids. She reports no weakness. A recent laboratory evaluation revealed a normal complete blood count, a normal urinalysis, and normal levels of serum creatinine and creatine kinase. Antinuclear antibody was not detected.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fat-pad biopsy, bone-marrow aspiration, and analysis of urinary porphyrins are unlikely to be helpful in this patient, because the features are not consistent with amyloidosis, a primary hematologic disorder, or porphyria, respectively.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's skin findings — a rash on the upper chest, erythema and edema of the eyelids, and erythematous papules over the knuckles — are most consistent with dermatomyositis. In the absence of muscle involvement, this presentation is consistent with amyopathic dermatomyositis and should prompt an evaluation for malignancy.

Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune condition that manifests with a cutaneous eruption, typically with proximal muscle weakness (classic dermatomyositis). In 10% to 20% of cases, there is no muscle involvement (amyopathic dermatomyositis). .

Patients with dermatomyositis are at increased risk for malignancy, particularly within the first 2 to 3 years after the onset of dermatomyositis. In one retrospective population-based study, 15% of patients with dermatomyositis were diagnosed with cancer either at the same time or in the 10 years after the diagnosis of dermatomyositis, reflecting a relative risk of 2.4 to 3.4 compared with the general population. Therefore, at a minimum, patients with dermatomyositis should undergo a thorough physical examination, laboratory testing, and age-appropriate guideline-recommended cancer-screening tests. In addition, most experts recommend CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis as well as mammography and transvaginal pelvic ultrasound.

Key learning point: The onset of either classic or amyopathic dermatomyositis in an adult should prompt a workup for malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of anti-double-stranded DNA antibody is unlikely to be helpful in this case, given that the patient has findings that are most consistent with a diagnosis of dermatomyositis rather than systemic lupus erythematosus, and she has a negative antinuclear antibody test. Of note, approximately one-third of patients with dermatomyositis can have a positive antinuclear antibody test.

D) INCORRECT:

Fat-pad biopsy, bone-marrow aspiration, and analysis of urinary porphyrins are unlikely to be helpful in this patient, because the features are not consistent with amyloidosis, a primary hematologic disorder, or porphyria, respectively.

E) INCORRECT:

Fat-pad biopsy, bone-marrow aspiration, and analysis of urinary porphyrins are unlikely to be helpful in this patient, because the features are not consistent with amyloidosis, a primary hematologic disorder, or porphyria, respectively.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl presents with concerns about weakness. For the past 2 weeks, she has had trouble climbing stairs, getting up from the couch, and keeping up with her peers during recess.
On examination, she is afebrile and has normal vital signs. Her heart, lung, and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. She has normal visual acuity, normal extraocular eye movements, and no facial asymmetry. Her eyelids and cheeks have a slight red-purple tinge (figure). She has 4/5 strength with shoulder abduction and adduction, flexion and extension of the elbows, hip flexion, and extension at the knee. She has normal grip strength and normal plantar and dorsiflexion at the ankle. Strength findings do not change on repeat examination, and she has no lid lag when looking up for 30 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch, and reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. She has a negative Romberg test, a normal tandem gait, and no finger-nose dysmetria.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most consistent with this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute inflammatory demyelinating disease. Myelin destruction leads to slower conduction of action potentials. This process affects longer nerves more than shorter nerves, leading to the classic ascending paralysis of GBS. It is unlikely to cause proximal weakness that is more prominent than distal weakness.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s history and physical examination reveal evidence of proximal muscle weakness. Trouble climbing stairs or getting out of a pool is often a hallmark of such weakness. In addition, this patient has a strong grip but weak deltoids, biceps, and triceps — as well as strong dorsiflexion and plantar flexion but weak hip flexors and weak flexion and extension at the knees. Weakness that is more pronounced in the proximal muscles than the distal muscles is suggestive of a myopathy. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM), an inflammatory myopathy that is characterized by symmetric proximal muscle weakness and cutaneous findings, such as a heliotrope rash on the eyelids and Gottron papules on the knuckles. Laboratory evidence of JDM typically includes elevated serum levels of creatine kinase, alanine aminotransferase, aspartate aminotransferase, lactate dehydrogenase, or aldolase — with confirmation by MRI of the legs, electromyography, or biopsy of the triceps. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level also tend to be elevated in JDM. Antibody testing results — including anti-p155, anti-p140, anti-melanoma differentiation-associated gene 5, and anti-signal recognition particle — are relatively specific for dermatomyositis.

Key learning point: The combination of bilateral proximal muscle weakness, an otherwise normal neurologic examination, and a heliotrope rash on the eyelids is suggestive of juvenile dermatomyositis.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease that is often characterized by a butterfly-shaped rash over the cheeks and bridge of the nose. Other symptoms include fatigue; joint pain, stiffness, and swelling; Reynaud phenomenon; dry eyes; and headaches. Although fatigue and joint pain can appear similar to weakness clinically, formal testing would not reveal true weakness.

D) INCORRECT:

Transverse myelitis is a myelopathy that can be infectious or inflammatory in origin. It can cause bilateral weakness but would not be expected to affect proximal muscles more than distal muscles.

E) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor at the postsynaptic end of the neuromuscular junction. It classically manifests with fatigability, as the limited number of acetylcholine receptors are already bound to their ligand and are inactivated as more acetylcholine is released upon repeated stimulation. Myasthenia gravis is unlikely to cause proximal weakness that is more prominent than distal weakness.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with one year of progressive weakness and difficulty walking. She had initially developed bilateral leg pain and a limp, offloading her right leg, with no joint swelling or stiffness. At first, her pain was responsive to ibuprofen, but over the next few months, her pain worsened and appeared to be accompanied by leg weakness. During the past few days, she started to crawl up the stairs or ask to be carried, which prompted the family to come in.
On examination, a positive Gower sign is noted. The patient also has purple discoloration of her eyelids and red papules over her elbows, knees, and several of her knuckles. Most recently, she has developed numerous subcutaneous nodules, which are palpable.
Radiographs of the pelvis are obtained (figure).
The disease complication shown in the radiograph is associated with which one of the following autoantibodies?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-MDA-5 antibody is associated with interstitial lung disease.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM), which accounts for about 80% of all idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (IIM) in children. Other subtypes of IIM include juvenile polymyositis and amyopathic dermatomyositis. Although the specific etiology of JDM is unknown, the disease is thought to be caused by an autoimmune reaction that occurs in genetically susceptible individuals who experience certain environmental triggers (such as an infection).

The primary manifestations of JDM are muscle and skin disease. Patients typically have symmetric proximal muscle weakness, which is reflected in the lower extremities by a positive Gower sign. The anterior neck flexors and trunk muscles are also frequently affected. Common cutaneous manifestations include heliotrope rash (described as a purple discoloration of the eyelids, occasionally with scaling) and Gottron papules (red papules over the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints, as well as over the extensor aspect of the elbows, knees, and medial malleoli).

A rare but significant cause of morbidity for patients with JDM is calcinosis, which is exhibited in this patient’s radiograph.

Calcinosis is caused by the deposition of calcium hydroxyapatite in the skin, soft tissue, or muscle. It can occur anywhere in the body but frequently occurs at pressure points (such as elbows, knees, and buttocks). It usually develops later in the disease course and can lead to overlying skin ulcers, pain, and joint contractures.

The presence or absence of myositis-specific antibodies in JDM patients can be helpful in predicting complications of the disease and thus guiding choices of therapy.

Anti-MJ antibody (which targets the autoantigen NXP2) is known for its association with calcinosis.

Key learning point: In a patient with juvenile dermatomyositis, calcinosis is associated with the autoantibody anti-MJ.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-SRP antibody is very rare and is associated with severe muscle weakness and very high creatine kinase levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibody is associated with antisynthetase syndrome, which is characterized by Raynaud phenomenon, interstitial lung disease, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers (“mechanic hands”), and nonerosive arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Mi-2 antibody is associated with skin disease and overall projects a milder course of illness.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl presents with 8 months of slowly progressive leg weakness and 4 months of unexplained rashes on her face and hands. On examination, she has a malar rash and purplish discoloration of the eyelids as well as erythematous papules over the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints of both hands. She can bear weight on both legs but places her hands on her thighs when rising from the floor and can only maintain her wrists above the top of her head for 10 seconds before fatiguing. She is referred to rheumatology and started on treatment with prednisone, methotrexate, and intravenous immunoglobulin. Her rashes and weakness improve substantially.
Ten months later, she is brought to the emergency department with 2 days of severe abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. On the day of presentation, she has bloody stools and increasing abdominal distention. A CT scan of the abdomen shows pneumoperitoneum.
Which one of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mesenteric artery aneurysm can occur in patients with systemic polyarteritis nodosa, a medium-vessel vasculitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intussusception is a feared complication of IgA vasculitis (formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura).

C) INCORRECT:

Lupus enteritis is a rare complication of systemic lupus erythematosus.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is consistent with gastrointestinal perforation as a complication of juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM). JDM is an autoimmune disease and the most common idiopathic inflammatory myopathy in children. Although the specific etiology of JDM is not known, vasculopathy is thought to play a central role in the pathogenesis of several of its clinical manifestations.

The primary features of JDM are myositis and cutaneous disease. Patients typically experience symmetric, proximal muscle weakness, which is reflected in the lower extremities by Gower sign. The anterior neck flexors and trunk muscles are also frequently affected. Common skin manifestations include a malar rash (which classically does not spare the nasolabial folds, as it does in systemic lupus erythematosus), a heliotrope rash (an erythematous to violaceous discoloration of the eyelids, occasionally with scaling), and Gottron papules (erythematous papules over the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints and over the extensor aspect of the elbows, knees, and medial malleoli).

Systemic glucocorticoids are the most widely used treatment for JDM; methotrexate and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) are commonly used as glucocorticoid-sparing agents.

Gastrointestinal perforation is a rare but significant cause of mortality in patients with JDM and is thought to be a consequence of gut vasculopathy. It typically manifests with severe abdominal pain and, in some cases, fever, vomiting, gastrointestinal bleeding, and abdominal distention (depending on the location of the perforation). Gastrointestinal perforation requires a high level of suspicion in patients with JDM because it can occur at any time in the disease course, including only mildly active disease. In a recently published case series, the most common sites of perforation were the duodenum and the colon. Despite prompt management with surgery and immunosuppressive agents, mortality rates are high.

Key learning point: Patients with juvenile dermatomyositis who present with severe abdominal pain should be urgently evaluated for intestinal perforation.

E) INCORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is most commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease, although it can also occur in other diseases (including infections, such as Clostridium difficile).

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman reports increasing muscle weakness in her shoulders and legs for 6 weeks. She is unable to climb stairs or comb her hair. She has also had difficulty swallowing food for the past week. Her symptoms do not improve with rest. Physical examination shows normal muscle tone. There is bilateral weakness of the iliopsoas, hamstring, deltoid, and biceps muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick, temperature, and vibration is intact. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Hemoglobin
10.7 g/dL


Leukocyte count
10,800/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
100 mm/h


Serum



 Creatine kinase

7047 U/L


 Lactate dehydrogenase
2785 U/L


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture (LP) is used to diagnose multiple sclerosis (MS) in patients with ambiguous MRI findings. MS can also cause muscle weakness, although the characteristic course of MS involves intermittent waxing and waning symptoms, not progressive weakness over the course of 6 weeks. Additionally, ESR and CK elevation would not be seen in MS. Finally, if MS were suspected, this patient would need an MRI before LP would be indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Electromyography (EMG) is used to differentiate neuropathic (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome, Guillain-Barré syndrome) from myopathic muscle weakness (e.g., PM, muscular dystrophy); results are abnormal in approx. 90% of patients with PM. If EMG findings are consistent with PM, a muscle biopsy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Other findings associated with PM include elevated antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) and myositis-specific antibodies (anti-Mi-2 and anti-Jo-1). Elevated ANA, a nonspecific finding in many autoimmune processes, is seen in one-third of patients with PM. Anti-Mi-2 antibodies are found in approx. 10% of patients with PM, while anti-Jo-1 antibodies are found in approx. 30%. Systemic corticosteroids are used in the initial treatment of PM. Immunosuppressants, IVIG, and plasmapheresis are reserved for refractory cases.

See “Differential diagnoses of myopathies” table.

C) INCORRECT:

An edrophonium/tensilon test was formerly used as a diagnostic test for myasthenia gravis (MG). Although MG can also lead to muscle weakness (including dysphagia), symptoms are usually worse late in the day and with exercise and better early in the day and after rest, which is not the case in this patient. Additionally, MG would not cause increased ESR or serum CK levels.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

D) INCORRECT:

A temporal artery biopsy is indicated in patients with suspected giant cell arteritis (GCA), a vasculitis that characteristically leads to elevated ESR. Polymyalgia rheumatica (PR) is an inflammatory condition that occurs in approximately half of patients with GCA (usually women above the age of 50 years). However, PR manifests with proximal muscle pain and stiffness, and not weakness, which is seen in this patient. PR would also not explain this patient's elevated CK levels or dysphagia.

E) INCORRECT:

Skin biopsy is a common diagnostic test in patients with suspected dermatomyositis. Like PM, dermatomyositis causes progressive proximal, symmetrical muscle weakness. However, the presence of skin involvement, such as a heliotrope rash or Gottron papules, is the main differentiating factor of dermatomyositis. This patient does not present with skin abnormalities so a skin biopsy is not indicated at this time.
questions.hint: Progressive proximal muscle weakness, dysphagia, elevated creatine kinase (CK) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) with normal skin findings indicate polymyositis (PM).

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of progressive weakness. She has had increased difficulty combing her hair and climbing stairs. She has hypertension. Her current medications include chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. A photograph of the patient's face is shown. Skin examination shows diffuse erythema of the upper back, posterior neck, and shoulders. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-centromere antibodies are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with limited cutaneous SSc, which may include CREST syndrome. The classic presentation of SSc involves thickening and hardening of the skin, sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc). This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are associated with Sjogren syndrome, an autoimmune disease involving the salivary and lacrimal glands. Patients with Sjogren syndrome typically present with dry mouth and dry eyes, and may also present with blurred vision, dysphagia, and dental caries. They can also have extraglandular symptoms, including fatigue, arthralgias, and the Raynaud phenomenon. Sjogren syndrome is not associated with a heliotrope rash or shawl sign, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-histone antibodies are a diagnostic marker of drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE). Common medications associated with DILE are procainamide and hydralazine, as well as isoniazid, quinidine, and sulfadiazine. DILE typically manifests with fever, polyarthritis, serositis, myalgia, and rash. This patient only takes chlorthalidone and vitamin supplements, however, and her rash is not typical for this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are specific to both dermatomyositis and polymyositis. The presence of anti-Jo-1 antibodies is associated with a more aggressive disease course and an increased risk for interstitial lung disease. Anti-Mi-2 antibodies may also present and are typically associated with a more favorable prognosis. Dermatomyositis is associated with several malignancies, and all patients diagnosed with dermatomyositis should undergo age-appropriate malignancy screening.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-Scl-70 antibodies (anti-topoisomerase) are associated with systemic sclerosis (SSc), especially with diffuse cutaneous SSc. In addition to the classic presentation of SSc, which includes sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastrointestinal symptoms (dysphagia, reflux, etc), this subset is more likely to have proximal extremity involvement and is associated with an increased risk of developing interstitial lung disease. This patient's heliotrope rash and shawl sign are not consistent with SSc.
questions.hint: This patient's proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign indicate dermatomyositis, an inflammatory myopathy (polymyositis) of the proximal skeletal muscles that is also characterized by skin involvement.
