questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of progressive weakness. She has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. Vital signs are normal. On examination, she has a violaceous rash over her eyelids. A photograph of her hands is provided. Muscle strength is 4/5 at the shoulders and hips, and normal elsewhere. This patient is at greatest risk for which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oat cell cancer is a type of highly aggressive small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung. Patients usually have an extensive smoking history and often present with cough and hemoptysis. Additionally, this cancer is associated with several paraneoplastic manifestations, including SIADH, Cushing disease, Lambert-eaton myasthenic syndrome, and opsoclonus-myoclonus ataxia syndrome, but not dermatomyositis.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with dermatomyositis are at increased risk of developing malignancies, particularly ovarian adenocarcinomas in the case of female patients. Other malignancies associated with inflammatory myopathies such as dermatomyositis include adenocarcinomas of the cervix, lungs, ovaries, and bladder. Diagnostic criteria for dermatomyositis include detection of anti-Mi-2 and anti-Jo-1 antibodies and parafascicular and perivascular infiltration with plasmacytoid dendritic cells and B lymphocytes on biopsy.

Key learning point: Dermatomyositis is associated with an increased risk of malignancy, especially ovarian adenocarcinoma in women.

C) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma can manifest with hypercalcemia secondary to paraneoplastic calcitriol production, but it is not associated with dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis is associated with non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytomas can arise as part of syndromes such as MEN 2, neurofibromatosis type 1, and von Hippel-Lindau disease. Most pheochromocytomas secrete epinephrine. If they secrete EPO, patients can develop polycythemia. They are not associated with dermatomyositis,

E) INCORRECT:

Renal clear cell carcinoma (RCC) is associated with several paraneoplastic complications, including hypercalcemia secondary to PTHrP release, polycythemia vera, Cushing disease, and hypertension. It is not associated with dermatomyositis.
questions.hint: Proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash over the eyelids, and flat-topped erythematous papules over the dorsal surface of interphalangeal joints (Gottron papules) are features of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the ED after several weeks of worsening muscle weakness. He says he struggles to get off the sofa and to get groceries out of his car. He denies numbness, pain, visual changes, or difficulty initiating movements. He has hypercholesterolemia and takes 20 mg of atorvastatin daily. Examination reveals symmetric weakness of the hip flexors and shoulder abductors (3/5) with normal sensation and brisk reflexes. Cranial nerves are intact. There is no muscle tenderness. Laboratory studies show creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) 5,600 U/L, AST 171 U/L, ALT 142 U/L, and normal thyroid studies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — This patient has painless subacute, symmetric proximal muscle weakness, markedly elevated CPK, and normal sensation and reflexes, which are characteristic of idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (e.g., polymyositis).

B) INCORRECT:

Guillain–Barré typically causes acute ascending weakness with areflexia and sensory symptoms. This patient has preserved reflexes, no sensory involvement, and subacute onset with high CPK, which point away from GBS and toward a primary myopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Statin myopathy is common in this age group and can cause proximal muscle weakness. However, it usually presents with muscle pain and mild CPK elevation (<2,000 U/L). This patient has painless weakness with a markedly elevated CPK (∼5,600 U/L), which is more consistent with another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroid myopathy can cause proximal weakness and elevated muscle enzymes, but the patient does not have systemic hypothyroid features (bradycardia, weight gain, delayed reflex relaxation) and thyroid studies are normal.

E) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis can cause fatigable limb weakness, but typically has fluctuating symptoms, bulbar or ocular involvement, normal CPK, and often worsens with exertion then improves with rest. This patient has progressive weakness, no reported improvement with rest, and an elevated CPK.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to the ED with progressive difficulty rising from chairs and lifting her arms over the past month. Examination shows symmetric weakness of the shoulder and hip girdle muscles (3/5) and facial rash (shown in photograph). Laboratory studies show creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) 6,200 U/L, AST 188 U/L, ALT 160 U/L, and normal electrolytes. She has normal oxygen saturation and is afebrile. Which of the following complications is this patient at risk for?

choices.text: Acute bacterial myositis from superimposed infection
Myasthenic crisis from neuromuscular junction failure
Respiratory failure from progressive muscle weakness
Acute ischemic stroke from large vessel vasculitis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infectious myositis presents acutely with fever, focal pain, and leukocytosis, unlike this subacute, painless symmetric weakness. Antibiotics are not indicated unless infection is suspected.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is often secondary to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and causes arterial and venous thrombosis, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. The violaceous eyelid rash in this patient may be mistaken for the malar rash of lupus, making APS seem plausible. However, her presentation of symmetric proximal muscle weakness and markedly elevated CPK is characteristic of idiopathic inflammatory myopathy, not APS. Thromboembolic events are not typical complications of inflammatory myopathies.

C) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) can mimic inflammatory myopathy with proximal limb weakness, making it a plausible consideration. However, MG typically causes fluctuating rather than progressive weakness, normal CPK levels, and no rash. This patient’s symmetric weakness and markedly elevated CPK are more consistent with idiopathic inflammatory myopathy, not MG.

D) CORRECT:

Correct — This patient has findings consistent with dermatomyositis, an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy, including proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash, and markedly elevated CPK. A major acute complication is respiratory muscle involvement, which can lead to hypoventilation and respiratory failure. Emergency clinicians should monitor lung function and be prepared to escalate care if her respiratory status declines.

E) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis, a large vessel vasculitis, is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), which causes shoulder and hip girdle pain and stiffness — this can be mistaken for the proximal weakness seen in idiopathic inflammatory myopathy. GCA can cause large-vessel vasculitis involving the aorta and its branches, leading to ischemic stroke (especially vertebrobasilar) and later aortic aneurysm or dissection. However, this patient has objective symmetric muscle weakness and markedly elevated CPK, which point to idiopathic inflammatory myopathy, not GCA/PMR.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 4-month history of progressive weakness. She reports increasing difficulty climbing stairs, rising from a seated position, and combing her hair. She also notes mild, diffuse muscle aches. She does not have any skin changes, vision problems, or difficulty swallowing. Muscle strength is 4/5 in her deltoids and hip flexors bilaterally, and 5/5 in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are normal, and sensation is intact. Laboratory studies show a creatine kinase level of 4,500 U/L. Which of the following is the most definitive diagnostic study for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the thighs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A skin biopsy is the definitive diagnostic test for dermatomyositis, which is a key differential diagnosis for polymyositis. However, this patient explicitly does not have any skin changes, such as a heliotrope rash or Gottron papules. Performing a skin biopsy in the absence of a rash would have no diagnostic value for her condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Electromyography (EMG) is a valuable tool in the workup of muscle weakness and would likely show a myopathic pattern (short-duration, low-amplitude polyphasic potentials) in this patient. However, while EMG can confirm a myopathy and rule out a primary neuropathy or neuromuscular junction disorder, its findings are not specific to inflammatory myopathies and can be seen in other muscle diseases. Therefore, it is a supportive test, not the most definitive one.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a sensitive, noninvasive method to detect muscle inflammation, which would appear as high signal intensity on T2-weighted images. However, the finding of muscle edema on MRI is not specific to inflammatory myopathies and can be seen in conditions such as rhabdomyolysis or muscular dystrophy, making it a supportive rather than a definitive test.

D) INCORRECT:

Testing for myositis-specific antibodies (e.g., anti-Jo-1, anti-Mi-2) may be considered as part of the evaluation of this patient because these antibodies can help classify the myositis subtype and predict associated features, such as interstitial lung disease. However, a significant number of patients with inflammatory myopathies are seronegative. Because a negative result does not rule out the disease, this panel is not considered the most definitive diagnostic study.

E) CORRECT:

A muscle biopsy is the most definitive diagnostic study for a patient with suspected IIM, because it provides direct histological evidence of the disease process. In polymyositis, the biopsy classically shows an endomyosial inflammatory infiltrate, primarily composed of CD8+ T cells, that surrounds and invades non-necrotic muscle fibers. A muscle biopsy not only confirms the diagnosis of polymyositis but also helps differentiate it from other myopathies, such as dermatomyositis (which shows perifascicular atrophy) and inclusion body myositis.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of symmetric, progressive proximal muscle weakness with a markedly elevated creatine kinase (CK) level is highly suggestive of an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy (IIM), such as polymyositis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressive weakness. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a violaceous rash over her eyelids. A photograph of her hands is shown. Muscle strength is 4/5 at the shoulders and hips but normal elsewhere. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytomas can arise as part of syndromes such as MEN 2, neurofibromatosis type 1, and von Hippel-Lindau disease. Most pheochromocytomas secrete epinephrine. If they secrete EPO, patients can develop polycythemia. They are not associated with dermatomyositis,

B) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma can manifest with hypercalcemia secondary to paraneoplastic calcitriol production, but it is not associated with dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis is associated with non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal clear cell carcinoma (RCC) is associated with several paraneoplastic complications, including hypercalcemia secondary to PTHrP release, polycythemia vera, Cushing disease, and hypertension. It is not associated with dermatomyositis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oat cell cancer is a type of highly aggressive small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung. Patients usually have an extensive smoking history and often present with cough and hemoptysis. Additionally, this cancer is associated with several paraneoplastic manifestations, including SIADH, Cushing disease, Lambert-eaton myasthenic syndrome, and opsoclonus-myoclonus ataxia syndrome, but not dermatomyositis.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with dermatomyositis are at increased risk of developing malignancies, particularly ovarian adenocarcinomas in the case of female patients. Other malignancies associated with inflammatory myopathies such as dermatomyositis include adenocarcinomas of the cervix, lungs, ovaries, and bladder. Diagnostic criteria for dermatomyositis include detection of anti-Mi-2 and anti-Jo-1 antibodies and parafascicular and perivascular infiltration with plasmacytoid dendritic cells and B lymphocytes on biopsy.
questions.hint: Proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash over the eyelids, and flat-topped erythematous papules over the dorsal surface of interphalangeal joints (Gottron papules) are features of dermatomyositis.
